title: I have MSA, and a stipulated judgement filed with the court. Is it dischargeable? what is the code of law?
question: My debt was discharged in bankruptcy court chapter 7. I have a stipulated judgement filed with the Superior court. My marital debt should not have been discharged in bankruptcy court, but it was. I would like to know the laws of non-dischargability of stipulated judgements and (MSA) in California. I am not asking about bankruptcy but focusing on laws governing Family Laws.
question_tags: Business contracts,Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy court,Debt,Debt discharge,Bankruptcy and debt,Representing yourself
answers: Your marital debt wasn't discharged - and by that I mean debt that you owed to the other spouse; what was discharged was 3rd party debt acquired during marriage and likely to be assigned to one or the other spouse. There are no family law codes regarding ability to discharge debts in bankruptcy - those laws are found only in the bankruptcy code. You might be inquiring as to the assignment of debt in family law and how it relates to a spouse's ability to discharge.

There is a presumption that domestic support obligations are not discharged in bankruptcy.
Debts that are unsecured and listed on a MSA may be discharged in a bankruptcy.
If the creditors are coming after you now understand that Family Law Courts are courts of limited jurisdiction. The jurisdiction was over the parties in front of the court. The creditors were not there so liability goes back to the original contract. The MSA allows you to bring the non compliant spouse back into Family Law Court on an Order to Show Cause why the non compliant spouse isn't complying with the MSA.
You may want to consult with a bankruptcy attorney yourself if the creditors are circling to collect from you.
I am tagging Family Law so that you will hopefully receive some more answer. I suggest you sit down with a local experienced family law attorney who has knowledge of bankruptcy laws.

The Bankruptcy discharge is granted without respect to the Superior Court's judgment. All of your dischargeable debt is discharged in a Chapter 7. You did not tell us when the MSA was entered, nor when you filed the Chapter 7. The answer will be very complicated, depending on whose debt was whose, You really should be speaking with a CA Family Law attorney, and there are some that answer family law questions on this site. However, you would be even wiser to use AVVO's Find an Attorney" button to find a local attorney who understands the intersection of Bankruptcy Law and Family Law. You really do not want to "cobble" and answer together from various attorneys here on AVVO with such a fact-intensive question. Believe me, it is not cut and dried according to the facts you have given us. Others may have different opinions, but ultimately, this is not a Do-it-yourself situation! This is really a Family Law matter, so I am opting to place it there. Other BK attorneys can still put in their two cents (some are worth quite a bit more on this site!). I have made my recommendation to seek a family law attorney. Now you will see that attorneys really do pay for themselves in Family Law. Yours should know this answer to your particular situation, but not if you went pro se.
